Frames are the same thing as complete Heyting algebras, with $x\to y$ = $\bigvee\{z\ |\ z\wedge x\leq y\}$. A morphism between frames is a map which preserves finite meets (hence, in particular, the top element 1) and arbitrary joins (hence, in particular, the bottom element 0). 

The category $\mathbf{Loc}$ of locales is the opposite of the category of frames. For an arrow $f:X\rightarrow Y$ in $\mathbf{Loc}$, we write $\Omega f:\Omega Y\rightarrow\Omega X$ for the corresponding morphism of frames. 

$\mathbf{Loc}$ has a terminal object $\mathbf{1}$ whose corresponding frame, usually written $\Omega$ instead of $\Omega\mathbf{1}$, is the power of a singleton set (the set of truth-values); this is the two-element set $\{0,1\}$ if and only if LEM holds. 

The following are some features of $\Omega$ that remain valid also intuitionistically. For all $p,q\in\Omega$, one has $p\leq q$ if and only if $p=1\Rightarrow q=1$. Moreover, $p\neq 1$ if and only if $p=0$ if and only if $-p$ = 1. Also, for $\{p_i\ |\ i\in I\}\subseteq\Omega$, one has $\bigvee_{i\in I}p_i=1$ if and only if $p_i=1$ for some $i\in I$.
 
For every locale $X$, we let $!_X$ be the unique map of locales from $X$ to $\mathbf{1}$. So $\Omega !_X(p)=\bigvee\{x\in\Omega X\ |\ x=1$ and $p=1\}$.
A locale $X$ is {\bf overt} if $!_X$, as a monotone map, has a left adjoint ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X$. Classically, every locale is overt. Even intuitionistically ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(x)\neq 1$ is equivalent to ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(x)=0$, which in turn is equivalent to $x=0$. However ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(x)=1$ is intuitionistically stronger than $x\neq 0$ and so ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(x)=1$ can be read as a positive way to express that $x$ is different from 0.

Every (sober) topological space determines a locale $X$, where $\Omega X$ is the frame of open sets. Locales obtained in this way are called {\bf spatial}. They are always overt and ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(x)=1$ means that the open set $x$ is inhabited. A locale $X$ is {\bf discrete} if $\Omega X$ is the power of a set. Discrete locales are spatial and correspond to discrete topological spaces.

\subsection{Sublocales}

A {\bf closure operator} on a poset $X$ is a map $c:X\rightarrow X$ such that the conditions $x\leq c(x)=c(c(x))$ and $x\leq y$ $\Rightarrow$ $c(x)\leq c(y)$ hold identically. We write $Fix(c)$ for the collection of all fixed points of $c$. Since $c$ is idempotent, $Fix(c)$ = $Im(c)$, the image of $c$. A {\bf nucleus} on a locale $X$ is a closure operator $j$ on $\Omega X$ that, in addition, preserves binary meets. In this case, $Fix(j)$ is a frame where finite meets are calculated in $\Omega X$ and joins are given by $j$-closure of those in $\Omega X$. 

The locale $X_j$ such that $\Omega X_j$ = $Fix(j)$ is a {\bf sublocale} of $X$ \cite{stone_spaces} and the mapping $x\mapsto j(x)$ is a regular monomorphism $X_j\hookrightarrow X$ in $\mathbf{Loc}$.\footnote{The map $x\mapsto j(x)$ from $\Omega X$ to $\Omega X_j$ is the coequalizer in the categories of frames of the two projections from $\{(x_1,x_2)$ $|$ $j(x_1)=j(x_2)\}$ (with pointwise operations) to $\Omega X$.} An example of nucleus is the map $x\mapsto--x$ (double negation nucleus).

For $j_1$ and $j_2$ nuclei, $X_{j_1}$ is a sublocale of $X_{j_2}$ if and only if $Fix(j_1){\subseteq } Fix(j_2)$ or, equivalently, if and only if $j_2(x)\leq j_1(x)$ for all $x\in\Omega X$.\footnote{$X_{j_1}$ corresponds to the nucleus on $X_{j_2}$ given by the mapping $j_2(x)\mapsto j_1(j_2(x))=j_1(x)$.} Thus sublocales, ordered by inclusion, are the opposite of $N(X)$, the set of nuclei with point-wise ordering, which is actually a frame \cite{stone_spaces}.

The join of a family $\{X_{j_i}\}$ of sublocales corresponds to the nucleus $\bigwedge_{i\in I}j_i$ which maps $x$ to $\bigwedge_{i\in I}j_i(x)$. Meets of sublocales are better seen from another perspective. Sets of the form $Fix(j)$, for $j$ a nucleus on $X$, are precisely the subsets of $\Omega X$ which are closed under arbitrary meets and which contain $x\rightarrow y$ whenever they contain $y$ (see \cite{stone_spaces} and \cite{pultr})).\footnote{If $S{\subseteq }\Omega X$ is such a subset, then the corresponding nucleus is $x\mapsto\bigwedge\{s\in S\ |\ x\leq s\}$.} Therefore, an arbitrary intersection of sets of that form still has the same form and so gives a sublocale.

We claim that the implication ${\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}={\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}$ $\Rightarrow$ ${\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}={\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}$ fails constructively as well as ${\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}={\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}$ $\Rightarrow$ ${\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}={\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}$. Each of them is equivalent to LEM. We prove this by constructing a family of topologies on the set $2=\{0,1\}$ of Boolean values\footnote{The argument works for every inhabited, non-singleton set.} such that ${\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}=id$ holds (where $id$ is the identity operator on subsets) and hence also ${\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}={\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}$ and ${\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}={\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}$ hold. Then we show that ${\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}=id$ (equivalently, ${\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}{\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}={\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}$) holds for all topologies in this class only if LEM holds.\footnote{Thus we also prove that the implication ${\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}}=id$ $\Rightarrow$ ${\mbox{\sf {\,int\,}}}=id$ is equivalent to LEM.}

Fix $p\in\Omega$. We put $P$ = $\{x\in 2\ |\ p=1\}$ and, for $D{\subseteq } 2$, we also put $Q_D=\{x\in 2\ |\ P{\subseteq } D\}$. Let us consider the family $\tau$ = $\{D{\subseteq } 2\ |\ D{\subseteq } P\cup Q_D\}$, which we claim to be a topology on $2$.\\ Clearly $\emptyset\in\tau$; also $2\in\tau$ because $Q_2=2$. Moreover if $D,E\in\tau$, then $D\cap E\in\tau$ because $Q_{D\cap E}$ = $Q_D\cap Q_D$. Finally, $\bigcup_{i\in I} Q_{D_i}$ ${\subseteq }$ $Q_{\bigcup_{i\in I} D_i}$ for every given set $I$. So if $D_i\in\tau$ for every $i$, then $\bigcup_{i\in I} D_i$ ${\subseteq }$ $\bigcup_{i\in I} (P\cup Q_{D_i})$ ${\subseteq }$ $P\cup \bigcup_{i\in I} Q_{D_i}$ ${\subseteq }$ $P\cup Q_{\bigcup_{i\in I}D_i}$.\\ We now claim that every subset $D{\subseteq } 2$ is closed in this topology. Let $x\in{\mbox{\sf {\,cl\,}}} D$ and choose $E=\{x\}\cup P$, which is open (because $Q_E=2$) and $x\in E$. Therefore $E{\, \between \,} D$; so either $x\in D$ or $P{\, \between \,} D$. This means that either  $p=1$ or $(p=1)\Rightarrow(0=1)$; hence $p\vee\neg p$ would always be 1.

nexttext:
We call it $R_X$. Thus
$x\leq R_X(y)$ if and only if ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge x)\leq{\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge y)$ for all
$z\in\Omega X$. Thereby \eqref{eq. def. j_exists} follows.
\end{proof}

As expected, when adopting classical logic $R_X$ reduces to the double-negation nucleus. Indeed, ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge x)\leq{\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge y)$ means ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge x)=1\Longrightarrow{\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge y)=1$ which, by classical logic, is equivalent to ${\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge y)\neq 1\Longrightarrow{\mbox{\sf {\,Pos}}}_X(z\wedge x)\neq 1$. The latter is just $(z\wedge y=0)\Rightarrow(z\wedge x=0)$, that is, $(z\leq-y)\Rightarrow(z\leq-x)$. For this to hold for all $z$ it is necessary and sufficient that $-y\leq-x$ or, equivalently, $x\leq--y$. 

Intuitionistically, one only has 
 $R_X(y)\leq --y$ for all $y$ and hence the double-negation sublocale $X_{--}$ is in fact a sublocale of $X_{R_X}$. 

Proposition \ref{prop. def. o-algebra} says that o-algebras are precisely the overt locales $X$ for which $R_X$ is the identity nucleus. Thus we obtain the following at once.
\begin{corollary}\label{corollary characterization o-algebras} An overt locale $X$ is an o-algebra if and only if it coincides with its own smallest overt, strongly dense sublocale. 
\end{corollary}
In other words, the smallest overt, strongly dense sublocale of an overt locale is an o-algebra and every o-algebra can be obtained in this way.

\section*{Conclusions}
The class of Boolean locales does not contain the discrete ones, intuitionistically. On the other hand the class of overlap algebras has the following features: (i) it contains discrete locales; (ii) it coincides with that of Boolean locales, classically; (iii) it corresponds to the smallest overt, strongly-dense sublocales (precisely as the Boolean locales correspond to smallest dense sublocales). Spatial overlap algebras are sober space in which every open is ``weakly'' regular. Classically, these are precisely the discrete spaces. Whether this fact is true intuitionistically or not is still an open question.
